reg:regulation.reg:acttitle: Community Care and Assisted Living Act
reg:regulation.reg:title: Assisted Living Regulation

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Community Care and Assisted Living Act;
class, in relation to an assisted living residence, means the applicable class established under section 3 [classes of assisted living residences];
contact person means an individual who is designated by a resident to act as the resident's contact person;
criminal record check means a criminal record check under the Criminal Records Review Act;
dietitian means a person who is authorized to practise dietetics under the Health Professions Act;
electronic surveillance means the use of electronic devices to transmit or record images of residents or members of the public;
emergency response plan means an emergency response plan made under section 25 [emergency response plan];

funding program means a program operated by a provincial, federal, municipal or first nations government, or an agency of any of them, from which funds are provided to a registrant on an ongoing basis for the purpose of providing hospitality services or assisted living services to residents;
health professional means a person who provides professional health services;
individual dietary plan means an individual dietary plan made under section 70 [managing therapeutic diets];
manager means an individual whom a registrant has authorized to manage the operation of an assisted living residence;
medication means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a drug within the meaning of the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act;
medical cannabis within the meaning of the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: medication policy means the medication policy made under section 37 [medication policy];
menu plan means a menu plan made under section 55 [menu plan];
opioid overdose means an overdose described in Schedule E that involves opioids;
personal representative includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a representative under the Representation Agreement Act,
an attorney acting under a power of attorney, and
a committee under the Patients Property Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: personal service plan means a personal service plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: made in accordance with section 33 [personal service plan], and
as revised, if applicable, under section 35 [review of personal service plan];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: reportable incident means a type of incident described in Schedule E for the purposes of section 51 [reportable incidents];
residency agreement means a residency agreement made under section 31 [residency agreement];
therapeutic diet means a diet described in section 70 [managing therapeutic diets];
transition plan means a transition plan made in accordance with section 45 [planned end of residency];
unit means a room or set of rooms in an assisted living residence that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: used as the personal living quarters of a resident, or
shared as personal living quarters by more than one resident.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Nothing in this regulation confers on a personal representative any greater authority to make financial, health or personal care decisions than the person has under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Representation Agreement Act, the Power of Attorney Act or the Patients Property Act,
a power of attorney, or
a representation agreement made under the Representation Agreement Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following classes of assisted living residences are established:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Mental Health, for adults receiving assisted living services due primarily to a mental disorder;
Seniors and Persons with Disabilities, for adults receiving assisted living services due primarily to chronic or progressive conditions linked to the aging process or a disability;
Supportive Recovery, for adults receiving assisted living services due primarily to substance use.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A residence that provides primarily emergency shelter is exempt for the purposes of section 2 [application] of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not qualified to be a registrant if the person is a limited liability partnership within the meaning of the Partnership Act.
A person is not qualified to be a registrant for the purpose of registering a particular premises unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: owns the premises,
leases the premises and is not prohibited under the terms of the lease from operating an assisted living residence on the premises, or
is authorized in writing by the owner of the premises to operate an assisted living residence on the premises.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may register an assisted living residence by submitting to the registrar all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a written application that includes the content described in Schedule A;
all applicable fees prescribed under section 7 (1) and (2) [application and registration fees];
a copy of the business licence issued for the premises or, if a business licence is not required for the premises, written confirmation of this from the local government that has jurisdiction;
a copy of the food service establishment permit issued for the premises, if a food service establishment permit is required under the Food Premises Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who intends to register an assisted living residence that has more than one class on the same premises must make a separate application for each class.
On applying to register an assisted living residence, an applicant must pay an application fee of $250 if any of the following circumstances apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the assisted living residence has not been registered before;
the assisted living residence has been registered before but the previous registration

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: expired or became invalid before the registrar received an application to renew that registration, or
was cancelled and the applicant is applying to have the assisted living residence registered again for the first time since the cancellation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the registrar advises an applicant that registration will be granted, the applicant must pay a registration fee as follows before registration begins:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if registration is to begin on or after March 31 but before October 1, $12.50 for each unit;
if registration is to begin on or after October 1 but before March 31 of the following year, $6.25 for each unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registration fee is payable in addition to the application fee, if any,
registration is not effective until the registration fee is paid, and
a fee paid under this section is not refundable.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must display in a prominent place in an assisted living residence a copy of the registration and any conditions of the registration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not make any change to either of the following unless, at least 30 days before the change, the registrant gives to the registrar written notice of the change:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contact information of the registrant or of the assisted living residence;
the name of the assisted living residence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not make any change to the manager of the assisted living residence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless, at least 30 days before the change, the registrant gives to the registrar

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: written notice of the change, and
the information respecting the manager that an applicant must provide under section 3 of Schedule A, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless the registrar first approves the change in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not make any change to the number of units in the assisted living residence or the number of residents the assisted living residence has the capacity to house

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless, at least 30 days before the change, the registrant gives to the registrar written notice of the change, and
unless the registrar first approves the change in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not make any change to the structure of the premises of the assisted living residence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless, at least 4 months before the change, the registrant gives to the registrar written notice of the change, and
unless the registrar first approves the change in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not make any change to the address or class of the assisted living residence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless, at least 4 months before the change, the registrant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: gives to the registrar written notice of the change, and
submits a new application in accordance with section 6 [requirements for registration] to register the assisted living residence, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless, before the change, a new registration is granted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not assign or otherwise transfer control of the operation of an assisted living residence unless,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an assisted living residence of any class, at least 4 months before the change, the registrant gives to the registrar, residents and residents' contact persons written notice of the change, and

in the case of an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class, the registrant also satisfies the registrar that the person to whom ownership or control will be assigned or otherwise transferred

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has applied, and is qualified, to be a registrant, and
will continue to operate the assisted living residence for at least one year from the date of assignment or transfer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a registrant is a corporation, a transfer occurs for the purposes of subsection (1) if more than 50% of the corporation's shares are assigned or otherwise transferred.

A registrant must not close and stop operating an assisted living residence unless the registrant gives to the registrar, residents and residents' contact persons written notice of at least the following duration, as applicable, before the scheduled date of closure:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 4 months, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class;
one year, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Waiver or modification of change requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may waive or modify a requirement of section 9 [notice to registrar of changes] or 10 [notice generally of changes] if the registrar is satisfied that the registrant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cannot, or failed to, comply with the requirement because of circumstances that could not reasonably have been foreseen by the registrant, and
attempted, as soon as reasonably practicable, to notify the registrar in writing that a waiver or modification is required.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may impose terms or conditions on a waiver or modification under subsection (1), and the registrant must comply with those terms and conditions, if any.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When registration ceases to be valid

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registration of an assisted living residence ceases to be valid as of the date that any of the following occur:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a condition of section 5 [qualifications for registrants] ceases to be met;
the address or class of the assisted living residence changes;
the registrant assigns or otherwise transfers control of the operation of the assisted living residence;
the assisted living residence has not provided housing, hospitality services and assisted living services for a period of one year;
the assisted living residence closes and stops operating.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a registrant is a corporation, a transfer occurs for purposes of subsection (1) (c) if more than 50% of the corporation's shares are assigned or otherwise transferred.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The registration of an assisted living residence expires March 31.
A registrant may apply to renew the registration of an assisted living residence by submitting to the registrar all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a written application describing any changes to the information and records provided in respect of the current registration, except changes for which notice was given under section 9 [notice to registrar of changes];
all applicable fees prescribed under section 7 (1) and (2) [application and registration fees].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: If more than one class or non-residents

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a registrant who operates an assisted living residence that, on the same premises,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has more than one class, or
houses both residents and non-residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who operates an assisted living residence to which this section applies must do the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that units for each class, and for residents and non-residents, are located in separate and distinct locations on the premises;
make a policy describing how the use of common areas shared by residents of more than one class, or by residents and non-residents, will be managed to protect the health and safety of residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not have more units, or house more residents, than is permitted under the registrant's registration.
A registrant must not house more residents in a unit than is consistent with protecting the health and safety of each resident.
A registrant must ensure that the assisted living residence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in a state of good repair and is safe, clean and free of hazards,
is maintained at a safe and comfortable temperature for residents,
is well-ventilated and has sufficient lighting in units and common areas, and
has sufficient social and recreational space for residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that residents requiring mobility aids may access, in a manner appropriate to each resident, all areas intended for use by residents.
A registrant must ensure both of the following with respect to the assisted living residence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the premises conforms to all enactments relevant to building alterations or occupancy limits;
that each unit is or includes a bedroom that has both a door and a window.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that furniture and equipment provided in common areas and units

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meet resident needs and capabilities,
are compatible with the health and safety of residents, and
are in a state of good repair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must provide, in each resident's unit, a lockable device for use by the resident to securely store money and other personal property, and
must, unless it would jeopardize the health and safety of other residents, permit residents to bring into the assisted living residence furniture, equipment and personal property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that the assisted living residence is secured in a manner that protects residents from entry by unauthorized persons.
A registrant must ensure that units are accessible in an emergency, including that locked units may be unlocked from the outside.
A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class must ensure both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that residents may lock their own units;
that, subject to subsection (2), residents may control access to their own units.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that emergency exits and egress windows are not obstructed or secured in a manner that may hinder exit in an emergency.
A registrant must not permit a weapon within the meaning of the Criminal Code in the assisted living residence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that, at all times, there are a sufficient number of employees with adequate training, experience, skills and other qualifications to provide hospitality services and assisted living services to residents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with the registrant's registration, and
in a manner that will not jeopardize the health and safety of residents.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must prepare an employee plan that includes a written description of all of the following for each employee position, whether volunteer or staff:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the duties and responsibilities of the employee;
the training, experience, skills and other qualifications the employee must have.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a registrant must not employ a person in an assisted living residence unless the registrant or manager

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has first obtained

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a criminal record check for the person,
a record of the person's work history,
copies of any diplomas, certificates or other evidence of the person's training, experience, skills and other qualifications, and
evidence that the person has complied with the Province's immunization and tuberculosis control programs, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is satisfied that the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is of good character,
has the personality, ability and temperament necessary to provide services to residents, and
has the training, experience and other qualifications, and demonstrates the skills, necessary to carry out assigned duties and responsibilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant may employ a person without meeting the requirements of subsection (1) (a) (ii) and (iii) and (b) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrant or manager has first met with the person and obtained a criminal record check and at least 2 character references for the person,
the person will be a volunteer, and
the person will not be responsible for any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: managing the provision of hospitality services to residents;
managing or providing assisted living services to residents;
monitoring the health and safety of residents or the operation of the assisted living residence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant may employ a person without meeting the requirements of subsection (1) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is providing hospitality services or assisted living services under a contract between the registrant and another person,
the person with whom the registrant has contracted is not an individual, and

the registrant has a contract, letter or other form of written assurance that the other person has obtained the information and is satisfied of the matters referred to in subsection (1) in respect of the person providing services.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person employed as a manager must not be a volunteer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional requirements for Supportive Recovery class

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 22 (1) [character and skill requirements], a registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class must not employ a person unless the person has completed a course, or a combination of courses, of at least 20 hours duration in one or more of the following subjects:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: counselling;
crisis intervention and conflict resolution;
psychosocial intervention for substance use disorders;
trauma-informed practice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a registrant may employ a person who does not meet the requirements of that subsection

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person will be a volunteer to whom section 22 (2) applies, or
if all of the following conditions are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person is employed for a period of no more than 3 months;
the registrant ensures that a written plan is made describing how the person will complete, within the 3 month period, the course requirements referred to in that subsection;
the person is not re-employed by the registrant unless the person has completed the course requirements in accordance with the plan referred to in subparagraph (ii).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the performance of each employee is reviewed regularly, and
the registrant or manager is satisfied that the employee demonstrates the skills needed to carry out the duties that the employee is assigned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of an employee to whom section 22 (3) applies, the registrant must have a contract, letter or other form of written assurance that the person with whom the registrant has contracted conducts the reviews and is satisfied of the matters referred to in subsection (1) of this section in respect of the employee.
A registrant must not permit an employee to carry out any duties for which the employee does not have the necessary training, experience, skills or qualifications.
A registrant must make an emergency response plan that describes all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the procedures to be followed to prepare for, mitigate, respond to and recover from an emergency at the assisted living residence;
the procedures to be followed to conduct emergency drills and the frequency with which they will be held;
the procedures to be followed to evacuate residents in an emergency, including any supports residents require to evacuate or move to a safer location;
a plan to ensure that residents continue to receive adequate hospitality services and assisted living services during and following an emergency.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An emergency response plan must be reviewed and, if appropriate, revised if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is a structural change to the assisted living residence, or
the support requirements of residents change significantly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that all employees, other than a volunteer to whom section 22 (2) [character and skill requirements] applies, are trained in the implementation of the emergency response plan, including in the use of equipment referred to in the plan.
A registrant must display prominently throughout the assisted living residence evacuation procedures and a diagram of the location of emergency exits.
A registrant must ensure that the assisted living residence has emergency exits and egress windows that are appropriate to resident needs and capabilities.
A registrant must ensure that reliable communication equipment is accessible to all employees during an emergency.
A registrant must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fire protection equipment is inspected, tested and maintained

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in accordance with the recommendations, if any, of the manufacturer, and
at least annually, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: other emergency equipment is inspected, tested and maintained in accordance with the recommendations, if any, of the manufacturer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must conduct fire and other emergency drills at least annually.

A registrant must ensure that, at all times, an employee who holds a valid first aid and CPR certificate, provided on completing a course that meets the requirements of Schedule B, is readily accessible to residents.
A registrant must have first aid supplies readily accessible to all employees.
This section applies only to registrants operating an assisted living residence of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Supportive Recovery class, or
the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class, if residents are at risk of experiencing opioid overdoses.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must make a plan describing the procedures to be followed to prevent and respond to opioid overdoses by residents.
Without limiting section 27 [first aid], a registrant must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that naloxone and related supplies are readily accessible to all employees and residents;
that all employees are trained in how to administer naloxone;
that all residents are given information respecting how to administer naloxone.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Before accepting a person as a resident, a registrant must first be satisfied, based on all available information, of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the person does not require care;
that the person is not prohibited, under section 26.1 [persons not allowed to reside in an assisted living residence] of the Act, from residing in the assisted living residence;
that the person may reside in the assisted living residence without jeopardizing the health and safety of that person or of any other resident, given

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that person's needs and capabilities, and
the assisted living services provided by or through the registrant.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Before making a residency agreement, a registrant must give to the prospective resident a copy of all of the following, and inform the prospective resident in a manner that is appropriate to that person's needs and capabilities of the contents of the materials given:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the shared common areas policy made under section 15 [if more than one class or non-residents], if applicable;
the visitation and communication policy made under section 41 (2) [visitors and communicating with non-residents], if applicable;
the complaint policy made under section 43 (1) [resident concerns and complaints];
the end of residency policy made under section 44 (1) [end of residency];
the medication policy, if applicable;
the cannabis policy made under section 48 (3) [tobacco, vapour products and cannabis].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant may accept a person as a resident by making a written residency agreement with the person that includes all of the applicable content set out in Schedule C.
Before making a residency agreement, a registrant must inform the prospective resident in a manner that is appropriate to that person's needs and capabilities of the contents of the agreement.
On signing a residency agreement, a registrant must give to the resident

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the residency agreement, and

written information respecting how to contact the registrar to make a complaint, including the registrar's contact information, and inform the resident in a manner that is appropriate to the resident's needs and capabilities of the contents of the materials given.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (3), a residency agreement must be signed by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resident or the resident's personal representative, and
the registrant, the manager or a person authorized to sign residency agreements on behalf of the registrant.

bcl:section.bcl:text: On accepting a person as a resident, a registrant must ensure that a short-term service plan is developed for the resident, containing sufficient information to guide employees in protecting and promoting the resident's health and safety until a personal service plan is developed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a personal service plan is developed for a resident that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes all of the applicable content set out in Schedule D,
provides sufficient detail to enable employees to understand their duties and responsibilities in achieving the objectives of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: protecting and promoting the resident's health and safety,
meeting the resident's needs, and
achieving the resident's personal goals, if applicable, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: takes into consideration the cultural, spiritual and personal preferences of the resident.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a personal service plan is developed within the following period after the resident starts to reside in the assisted living residence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 7 days, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class;
30 days, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a personal service plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is developed with the participation of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the resident, and
to the extent it is reasonably practicable to do so, the persons whom the resident requests to participate, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is approved by the resident.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must give to the resident a signed copy of the resident's personal service plan.
For the purposes of subsection (4), a personal service plan must be signed by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resident or the resident's personal representative, and
the registrant, the manager or a person authorized to sign personal service plans on behalf of the registrant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a resident's personal service plan is implemented.
A registrant must ensure that the implementation of a resident's personal service plan is monitored regularly to ensure that the plan is achieving its objectives.
A registrant must ensure that a resident's personal service plan is reviewed as follows and revised, if appropriate:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least monthly, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class;
at least annually, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class;
on request of the resident;
if monitoring under section 34 (2) [implementation of personal service plan] indicates that the personal service plan is not meeting the plan's objectives;
if there is any substantial change to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the resident's needs or capabilities, or
the nature or scope of the hospitality services or assisted living services being provided to the resident.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 33 (3) [personal service plan] applies to the revision of a resident's personal service plan.
On request of a resident, a registrant must give to the resident a signed copy of that resident's revised personal service plan, and section 33 (5) applies for this purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must display in a prominent place in the assisted living residence a statement of the rights of residents.
A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class must make a policy describing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the types of medications that are accommodated on the premises, and
the medications, if any, that are not permitted on the premises.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not do any of the following unless one of the circumstances described in subsection (2) applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: intervene in the making of a personal decision by a resident or when a resident is carrying out a personal decision;
prevent a resident from carrying out a personal decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant may intervene or prevent a resident from carrying out a personal decision in any of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is an imminent risk of serious harm to the resident;
the resident may be subject to abuse within the meaning of Schedule E;
the failure to intervene or to prevent the resident from carrying out the decision may

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: jeopardize the health or safety of other persons, or
be neglect within the meaning of Schedule E;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrant is acting in accordance with the resident's residency agreement or personal service plan;
the registrant is taking an action required or permitted under the Adult Guardianship Act or another enactment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must, to the greatest extent possible while maintaining the health and safety of all residents, ensure respect for the personal privacy of each resident, including the privacy of each resident's unit, belongings and storage area.
A registrant must not use electronic surveillance in a unit or washroom.
A registrant must do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: monitor residents' health and safety, taking reasonable steps to avoid undue interference with personal privacy;
advise a resident and, if appropriate, a resident's contact person if the resident's health or safety is or may be jeopardized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For greater certainty, a registrant who complies with this section does not contravene any of the following sections:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 38 [respect for personal decisions];
section 39 [respect for resident privacy];
section 61 (3) [decisions respecting health professionals or medication].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class must, to the greatest extent possible while maintaining the health and safety of all residents, ensure that a resident may receive at any time, and communicate privately with, visitors of the resident's choice.

A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class must make a policy respecting visitation by and communication with non-residents, including any restrictions on these activities.

At least annually, a registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Mental Health or Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class must survey all residents to determine resident satisfaction with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the operation of the assisted living residence, and
the provision of hospitality services and assisted living services.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must make a record describing the findings of the survey.
A registrant must make a policy describing all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: how residents and their contact persons and personal representatives, if any, may bring a concern or make a complaint to the registrant about any matter relevant to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the operation of the assisted living residence,
the provision of hospitality services and assisted living services, or
the implementation of their residency agreements;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: how concerns will be addressed and complaints will be resolved in a fair, timely and effective manner.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must display in a prominent place in the assisted living residence the information described in section 31 (3) (b) [residency agreement] respecting complaints to the registrar.
If a concern is brought or a complaint is made to the registrant, the registrant must do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make reasonable attempts to address the concern or resolve the complaint;
make a record of the concern or complaint and the actions taken under paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a resident is not subject to either of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: interference or obstruction, including by intimidation, if the resident wishes or attempts to contact the registrar to make a complaint;
retaliation as a result of concerns brought or complaints made to the registrant, or complaints made to the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must make a policy describing the procedures to be followed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to determine if a resident may no longer reside in the assisted living residence, and
to end the resident's residency.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must not end a resident's residency on the basis that the resident is unable to make, on their own behalf, decisions that are necessary to live safely, unless the registrant does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensures that the resident's decision-making capacity has been assessed, before ending the resident's residency, by a health professional referred to in subsection (3);
keeps a record of the results of the assessment;
ensures that the resident and, if appropriate, the resident's contact person and personal representative, if any, have a copy of the record.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are health professionals for the purposes of subsection (2) (a):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: medical practitioners;
registrants of the British Columbia College of Nurses and Midwives who are subject to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Nurses (Registered) and Nurse Practitioners Regulation, or
the Nurses (Registered Psychiatric) Regulation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: registrants of the British Columbia College of Social Workers;
registrants of the College of Occupational Therapists of British Columbia;
registrants of the College of Psychologists of British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a transition plan is developed for a resident that provides for ending a resident's residency if any of the following circumstances occur:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resident's needs and capabilities change such that the resident requires care or is no longer allowed, under section 26.1 [persons not allowed to reside in an assisted living residence] of the Act, to reside in the assisted living residence;
the resident no longer requires assisted living services;
the resident expresses an intention to end the resident's residency;

the resident resides in an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class and chooses to use a medication that is not permitted under the medication policy of the assisted living residence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a transition plan describes all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when and by whom the resident will be moved out of the assisted living residence, and, if known, where the resident will be moved to;
how any risks to the health and safety of the resident will be minimized before, during and after the move,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: including any changes to the assisted living services that will be provided to the resident while awaiting the move, and

including, in the case of an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class, information or referrals respecting access to housing supports, professional health services and social services after the move.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a transition plan is developed with the participation of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resident,
if the resident is the beneficiary of a funding program and to the extent it is reasonably practical to do so, a representative of the funding program, and
one or more of the following, if and as requested by the resident and to the extent it is reasonably practical to do so:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the resident's contact person;
the resident's personal representative, if any;
the resident's medical practitioner, nurse practitioner, or other appropriate health professional.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a resident's residency ends unexpectedly, whether because the resident abandons the assisted living residence or is required to leave under the terms of the resident's residency agreement, a registrant must do all the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify the person's contact person and, if the person is the beneficiary of a funding program, a representative of the funding program;
unless it would not be reasonably practicable to do so, provide to the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: information respecting access to housing supports, professional health services and social services, and
a personal naloxone kit if the person is at risk of experiencing an opioid overdose;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make a record of the event and of the actions taken under paragraphs (a) and (b).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must make a plan describing the procedures to be followed to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promote general health and hygiene amongst residents, and
prevent the spread of infectious disease in the assisted living residence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: activated e-cigarette has the same meaning as in the Tobacco and Vapour Products Control Act;
cannabis has the same meaning as in the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;
e-cigarette has the same meaning as in the Tobacco and Vapour Products Control Act;
medical cannabis has the same meaning as in the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;
restricted activity means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an activity that constitutes restricted consumption;
the growth or storage of cannabis;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: restricted consumption means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to smoke or use tobacco or hold lighted tobacco;
to use an e-cigarette or hold an activated e-cigarette;
to smoke or vape cannabis;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: smoke or vape cannabis has the same meaning as in section 60 of the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;
tobacco has the same meaning as in the Tobacco and Vapour Products Control Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: no one other than a resident engages in a restricted activity while on the premises of the assisted living residence,
employees do not engage in restricted consumption while providing services to residents, and
if necessary for the safety of the resident, a resident who engages in restricted consumption is supervised.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must make a policy respecting all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the engagement by residents in restricted activities, other than the consumption of medical cannabis, on the premises;
the possession and disposal by anyone of tobacco, e-cigarettes and cannabis, other than medical cannabis, on the premises.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that the policy required under subsection (3)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes any restrictions on those activities on the premises, and
is consistent with the prohibitions and restrictions under the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act or the Tobacco and Vapour Products Control Act, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, "FOODSAFE certificate" means a certificate, issued by a health officer within the meaning of the Public Health Act, evidencing the successful completion of the food handler training program known as FOODSAFE or its equivalent.
A registrant must ensure that food and fluids provided by the registrant to residents are prepared, stored, served and handled safely.
A registrant must ensure that at least one employee who holds a current FOODSAFE certificate is present at the assisted living residence while food is prepared, served and handled.
Nothing in subsection (2) or (3) prevents residents from preparing their own food or fluids.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that a resident is not, in the course of receiving hospitality services or assisted living services, subjected to any type of abuse or neglect described in Schedule E.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if a resident is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subject of or witnesses a type of incident described in Schedule E, or
the subject of an alleged or suspected incident of any type of abuse or neglect described in Schedule E.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must do all of the following if this section applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: take immediate and appropriate action to respond to the incident;
within 24 hours of the incident, report the incident to all of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the registrar, in the form and manner required by the registrar;
the resident's contact person, if appropriate, and any other person the resident requests;
if the resident is the beneficiary of a funding program, a representative of the funding program;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make a record of the reportable incident and of the actions taken under paragraph (a).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must make a plan describing the procedures to be followed on becoming aware that a resident is a missing person within the meaning of Schedule E.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the registrar reasonably believes that the health or safety of residents may be jeopardized, the registrar may require a registrant to make a plan to protect the health and safety of residents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: after conducting an inspection, or
on receiving a report respecting a reportable incident or a complaint.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant subject to a requirement made under subsection (1) must comply within the time required by the registrar and with any directions given by the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that hospitality services are provided to residents in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promotes resident independence, and
does not jeopardize the health or safety of residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, Canada's Food Guide means the current edition of the publication produced by or on behalf of the Government of Canada that promotes nutritional health by guiding food selection.
A registrant must ensure that a menu plan is developed that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describes the meals, fluids and snacks for each day over at least a 4 week cycle,
is consistent with the recommendations set out in Canada's Food Guide, and
provides for a variety of foods and fluids, taking into consideration the nutritional needs and cultural, spiritual and personal preferences of residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must consult with a dietitian

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to make an initial menu plan, and
to review and, if appropriate, revise the menu plan if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the daily menu changes significantly, or
5 years have passed since the menu plan was last reviewed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a food or fluid is substituted for a food or fluid described in a daily menu, a registrant must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the daily menu remains consistent with the recommendations set out in Canada's Food Guide, and
residents are informed of the substitution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that all meals, fluids and snacks provided to residents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are consistent with the menu plan,
are palatable and safe for residents, taking into consideration residents' needs and capabilities, and
are provided in sufficient portions to meet residents' needs and ensure adequate hydration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Nothing in subsection (1) prevents residents from preparing their own meals, fluids or snacks.
A registrant must post or otherwise provide to residents the daily menu and meal times.
A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class must ensure that residents may access meal services, including by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assisting residents to attend the dining room,
providing meals in units for those residents who are temporarily confined, due to medical reasons, to their units, and
providing dishes, cups and cutlery appropriate to residents' needs and capabilities.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must provide housekeeping services that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include, at the least, sufficient cleaning of the premises, including regular cleaning of hard surfaces, to prevent disease and ensure a safe, clean and sanitary environment, and
take into consideration the needs and capabilities of residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, linens means bed sheets, blankets, towels and face cloths.
A registrant must provide linens to residents who require them.
A registrant must ensure that linens are clean, dry and in good condition, and are laundered

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least weekly, and
more often as needed to maintain resident health and meet resident needs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must provide to residents either personal laundry service or laundry equipment for resident use.
A registrant must provide to residents a program of social and recreational activities that are appropriate to resident needs, capabilities and preferences.
A registrant must post or otherwise provide to residents a calendar of the program of social and recreational activities.

A registrant who operates an assisted living residence of the Seniors and Persons with Disabilities class must ensure that safe transportation is provided to residents if social and recreational activities take place outside the assisted living residence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must provide to residents a 24 hour emergency response system that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enables residents to summon help during a personal emergency, and
is accessible to residents in a manner appropriate to resident needs and capabilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that assisted living services are provided to residents in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promotes resident independence, and
does not jeopardize the health or safety of residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that assisted living services are provided

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a resident in accordance with the resident's personal service plan, and
by individuals who have the necessary training, experience, skills and other qualifications to provide the service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), a registrant must not intervene in the making of a decision by a resident or when a resident is carrying out a decision, or prevent a resident from carrying out a decision, to do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receive a particular professional health service;
receive a professional health service from a person the resident chooses, including a person who is not employed by the registrant;
take a particular medication, if prescribed by a health professional;
receive a medication from a particular pharmacy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) of this section does not apply in any of the circumstances listed in section 38 (2) (a), (b), (c) or (e) [respect for personal decisions].

Nothing in this Division authorizes a registrant to perform an activity that the registrant is prohibited from performing under the Health Professions Act, the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act or any other enactment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with activities of daily living must do so in a manner that takes into consideration residents' safety, needs, capabilities and preferences.
In paragraph (b) of the definition of "assisted living services" in section 1 of the Act, assistance with managing medication includes one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receiving residents' medication from a pharmacy;
safekeeping medication on behalf of residents;
distributing medication to residents from the place where it is kept;
administering medication to residents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with managing medication must make a plan describing the procedures to be followed to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that assistance with managing medication is provided in a manner that does not jeopardize health or safety, and
prevent theft of medication, if the registrant provides assistance with receiving, safekeeping or distributing medication.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with managing medication must make a record for each resident receiving the service that includes a list of the resident's medications.

A registrant who provides assistance with managing medication must support and encourage those residents who have the ability to do so without jeopardizing their health or safety to self-manage medication.
A registrant who provides assistance with safekeeping medication must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consult with a pharmacist within the meaning of the Health Professions Act for the purpose of making and revising the plan referred to in subsection (1), and
keep a record of the results of the consultation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with safekeeping medication must ensure all of the following with respect to medication kept in the assisted living residence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that medication is kept

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: safely and securely, and
in accordance with the directions, if any, of the dispensing pharmacy;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that an inventory of medication is maintained;
that medication is kept in its original, labelled container until the medication is distributed or administered;
that medication is returned to a pharmacy if the medication

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has expired,
is no longer used by the resident to whom the medication was prescribed, or
was prescribed to a person who no longer resides in the assisted living residence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with distributing medication must ensure that a record is made in respect of each distribution of medication.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with administering medication must ensure that medication is administered only by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resident, or
a health professional, or a certified non-registrant within the meaning of the Health Professions Act, who is authorized under that Act to administer the medication.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with administering medication must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if, under the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act, a particular medication is available only on the prescription of a health professional, that the medication is administered to a resident only if that medication has been prescribed for the resident by a health professional;
that medication prescribed by a health professional for a resident is administered to the resident as prescribed;
that a record is made

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in respect of each administration of medication to a resident, and
of each error made in administering medication, if any, to which section 51 [reportable incidents] does not apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In paragraph (c) of the definition of "assisted living services" in section 1 of the Act, assistance with the safekeeping of money and other personal property includes holding or safekeeping on behalf of a resident one or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: money intended to be used by the resident for daily expenses;
personal property belonging to the resident.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant does not provide assistance with the safekeeping of money and other personal property solely because the registrant provides a lockable device in accordance with section 18 (2) (a) [furniture and equipment].
A registrant who provides assistance with the safekeeping of money and other personal property must not hold or keep, for any resident, money in an amount totalling more than $300.
A registrant who provides assistance with the safekeeping of money and other personal property must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep for each resident a record that includes all of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a current accounting of the money and a current inventory of the personal property held;

a record of the amount of money and personal property the registrant gave to or received from the resident or the resident's contact person or personal representative, if any, and the date it was given or received, including amounts given or received when that resident's residency ended;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on request of a resident, give to the resident a copy of the record referred to in paragraph (a);
if the resident consents, give to the resident's contact person or personal representative, if any, a copy of the record referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with the safekeeping of money and other personal property is not required to calculate or pay interest on money held for residents.
In paragraph (d) of the definition of "assisted living services" in section 1 of the Act, assistance with managing therapeutic diets includes providing to a resident a diet that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: modifies the meals, fluids or snacks described in a menu plan,
is or is part of a treatment plan for the resident's medical condition, and
controls the intake of particular foods or nutrients.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a resident requires a therapeutic diet, the registrant must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an individual dietary plan is developed, in consultation with a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian, that gives instructions respecting how meals, fluids or snacks are to be modified, and
the therapeutic diet is provided in accordance with the individual dietary plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with managing therapeutic diets must support a resident to adhere to the resident's therapeutic diet.

In paragraph (e) of the definition of "assisted living services" in section 1 of the Act, assistance with behaviour management includes supporting a resident to reduce and manage occurrences of behaviours that negatively affect the resident's health, safety or quality of life.

A registrant who provides to a resident assistance with behaviour management must ensure that, in consultation with an appropriate health professional who has first assessed the resident's needs and capabilities, a behaviour management plan is developed for the resident and revised as appropriate.
A registrant who provides assistance with behaviour management must support a resident to adhere to the resident's behaviour management plan.

In paragraph (f) of the definition of "assisted living services" in section 1 of the Act, assistance with psychosocial supports includes providing to a resident, or assisting a resident to participate in, programs designed to promote

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: basic living skills, including communication, interpersonal and planning skills,
wellness management, and
community integration and engagement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant who provides assistance with psychosocial supports must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make a policy

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: describing the nature and scope of the programs to be provided,
describing how the objectives described in subsection (1) are to be achieved through those programs, and
identifying which programs must be delivered by health professionals;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that programs are appropriate to resident needs and personal goals;
ensure that programs are appropriate given resident readiness to participate;
post or otherwise provide to residents a calendar of the programs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must ensure that all plans and policies that must be made under this regulation are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: made in writing,
implemented,
available to employees having relevant duties and responsibilities, and
available to residents and, on request of a resident, the resident's contact person and personal representative, if any, except

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the employee plan made under section 21 [employee plan], and
a plan made in respect of a specific resident.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must monitor and review regularly all operations of the assisted living residence to ensure compliance with the Act and this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of carrying out a duty under this Act, a registrant may do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seek the consent, in writing, of a prospective resident or a resident to the collection and disclosure of personal information;
if consent under paragraph (a) is granted, request a health authority to disclose to the registrant personal information respecting the prospective resident or resident.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must not permit an employee to access the records and personal information of a resident except as necessary for the performance of the employee's duties.
A registrant must keep a record for each resident that includes at least the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resident's name and the date on which the person's residency started;
the resident's original, signed residency agreement and any renewals and changes made to the agreement;
the name and current contact information of the resident's contact person and personal representative, if any;
a current copy of the resident's signed personal service plan and transition plan;
records made in respect of the resident under sections 43 (3) (b) [resident concerns and complaints], 51 (2) (c) [reportable incidents] and 67 (2) (c) [administering medication], if any;
a record of accidents, illnesses or medication errors, if any, involving the resident that do not require medical attention and are not reportable incidents.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must keep the following records:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for each employee,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the employee's name and the date on which the employee's employment began,
the employee's job title and a notation of whether the employee is staff, a contractor or a volunteer, and
a copy of the records required under sections 22 (1) [character and skill requirements] and, if applicable, 23 (1) [additional requirements for Supportive Recovery class];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: records made or obtained for the purpose of ensuring compliance with sections 22 (3) and 24 (2) [continuing obligations].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Length of time records must be kept

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4), a registrant must keep all records referred to in this regulation for at least one year.
A registrant must keep a record referred to in section 76 [resident records] for at least 2 years from the date the residency of the resident who is the subject of the record ends.
A registrant must keep all signed original forms authorizing criminal record checks to be done until the earlier of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 5 years from the date on which the form was signed;
the date on which the employment of the employee who is the subject of the form ends.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant must keep all records required under section 77 [employee records] for the entire time that the subject of the records is an employee.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant must make all records referred to in this regulation available to the registrar on request of the registrar and within the period requested.
The prescribed period within which the registrar must publish information for the purposes of the following is 30 days:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sections 25.5 (1) [publication of reports respecting registered residence] and 25.6 (1) and (2) [publication of reports respecting unregistered residence] of the Act;
section 8 (1) (a) of the Community Care and Assisted Living Amendment Act, 2018.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 25.1 [inspection of registered assisted living residences] and 25.2 [powers in relation to unregistered premises] of the Act, the registrar may request, by telephone or other means of telecommunication, a warrant authorizing entry into the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the personal residence of a resident;
unregistered premises.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A registrant may make an appeal to the board in writing, in the form specified by the board.
An applicant for registration must submit with the application all of the content set out in this Schedule.
An applicant must provide all of the following with respect to the applicant:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: name, address and contact information;
if the applicant is not an individual,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the applicant's legal status, being a corporation, society, partnership or other body, and
the name, address and contact information of each member of the board of directors or each partner, as applicable, and of the individual who is the applicant's representative;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the applicant is an individual, a criminal record check and 3 character references;

if the applicant is a corporation, a criminal record check and 3 character references for each board member who will be ordinarily present on the premises of the assisted living residence while residents are present;
if the applicant is an individual,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of government-issued photographic identification,
a record of the applicant's work history, and
copies of any diplomas, certificates or other evidence of the applicant's training, experience, skills and other qualifications;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proof, in a form satisfactory to the registrar, that the applicant is qualified to be a registrant for the purposes of section 5 (2) [qualifications for registrants].

bcl:section.bcl:text: If an applicant will not be the manager of the assisted living residence, the applicant must provide all of the following with respect to the manager:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name, address and contact information of the individual who is to be the manager;
a criminal record check and 3 character references for that individual;
a record of the individual's work history;
copies of any diplomas, certificates or other evidence of the individual's training, experience, skills and other qualifications.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An applicant must provide all of the following with respect to the assisted living residence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name by which the assisted living residence is known and the address and contact information of the assisted living residence;
a floor plan

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: drawn to scale and showing the location of each unit, common area, washroom and exit, and
showing which suites are resident units if, on the same premises, both residents and non-residents will be housed;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the number of units in the assisted living residence, and
for each unit, the maximum number of persons who may reside in the unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant must provide all of the following with respect to the operation of the assisted living residence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the class of the assisted living residence;
a detailed description of the nature and scope of the hospitality services and assisted living services to be provided to residents;
the number of residents for whom the assisted living residence has the capacity to provide housing, hospitality services and assisted living services.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant must provide a copy of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all plans and policies that must be made under the regulation except plans made in respect of specific residents;
the statement of the rights of residents that must be posted under section 36 [rights of residents].

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 27 (1) [first aid] of the regulation, the employee must hold a valid first aid and CPR certificate from a course that meets the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the course must offer at least 8 hours of instruction, at least 3.5 hours of which must be delivered in person;
the course instructor must have the qualifications necessary to train employees in the skills referred to in section 2 of this Schedule;
the first aid certificate

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is issued only after the employee has successfully completed an examination that includes demonstration and evaluation of the skills referred to in section 2 of this Schedule,
is signed by the instructor or is verifiable using a system established and maintained by the issuer of the certificate,
includes the employee's name, the level of first aid training achieved by the employee and the name of the agency that provided the training,
expires no more than 3 years from the date of issue, and

is not renewable unless the employee, before the expiry date, participates in at least 8 hours of further instruction, at least 3.5 hours of which must be delivered in person, followed by an examination that includes demonstration and evaluation of the skills referred to in section 2 of this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A first aid course is not sufficient for the purposes of section 27 of the regulation unless the course provides instruction in, and requires successful completion of an examination that includes demonstration and evaluation of skills relevant to, all of the following matters, taking into consideration the type of residents the employee ordinarily encounters in the assisted living residence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: management of an emergency scene;
assessment of a patient;
fainting and unconsciousness;
cardiopulmonary resuscitation skills recognized by the agency referred to in section 1 (c) (iii) of this Schedule as "(CPR) Level B" or a program that is equivalent;
shock;
choking;
wounds and severe bleeding;
insect, animal and human bites;
eye injuries;
spinal and head injuries;
dental emergencies;
fractures of the upper and lower limbs, including bone and joint injuries;
cardiovascular emergencies, including the use of automated external defibrillators;
burns;
electric shock;
poisoning;
environmental injuries, including exposure to heat or cold;
common medical conditions, including diabetes, epilepsy, convulsions and allergic reactions;
in the case of an employee of an assisted living residence described in section 28 (1) [opioid overdoses], opioid overdose;
breathing and airway emergencies.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A residency agreement must include all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the names of the registrant and the resident;
the name and contact information of the manager, if the registrant is not the manager;
the names and contact information of the resident's contact person and personal representative, if any;
the purposes for which the registrant may contact the resident's contact person and personal representative, if any.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A residency agreement must include both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date on which the residency agreement is made;
the date on which the resident is to start residing in the assisted living residence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: All of the following must be described in a residency agreement:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrant's duties and responsibilities;
the hospitality services and assisted living services provided by the registrant, including dietary accommodations, if any;
the general level and type of training, experience, skills and other qualifications of the employees who provide assisted living services;
the rules of the assisted living residence;
any electronic surveillance or tracking used at the assisted living residence;
the rights of residents as those rights relate to residing in the assisted living residence;
the resident's responsibilities;
whether any persons residing in the assisted living residence are not residents and, if so, whether those persons will have access to the common areas of the assisted living residence;
the circumstances under which the resident may no longer reside in the assisted living residence and the criteria that will guide a decision to end the resident's residency.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A residency agreement must include all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an itemized list of all fees payable by the resident for residency;
a description of the circumstances under which the fees referred to in paragraph (a) may change;
a statement of when residency fees are due;
a description of all optional services and the fees for each of them;
the terms and conditions for the payment and refund of fees;
a statement of the amount of any security or damage deposit paid or payable.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A residency agreement must describe all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the circumstances in which the residency agreement may be changed;
the procedures to be used to change the residency agreement, including respecting the giving of advance notice of proposed changes;
the changes, if any, that the registrant may make to the residency agreement without the consent of the resident.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In addition to the content set out in sections 1 to 5 of this Schedule, a residency agreement in respect of an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class must include all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the service model to be used;
the restrictions, if any, on

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the furniture, equipment and personal property that residents may bring into the assisted living residence, and
visitation by and communication with non-residents, including communication using electronic devices;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the types of medications, if any, that are not permitted on the premises.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General hospitality and assisted living services

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A personal service plan must identify, and describe the nature and scope of, the hospitality services and assisted living services to be provided to a resident, taking into consideration the resident's needs, capabilities and preferences.

A personal service plan must not include a hospitality service or an assisted living service that has not been approved by the resident under section 33 (3) (b) [personal service plan] of the regulation.
If a resident requires a therapeutic diet, the resident's personal service plan must include an individual dietary plan.
If a resident is receiving assistance with behaviour management, the resident's personal service plan must include a behaviour management plan.

If a resident is receiving assistance with managing medication, the resident's personal service plan must describe the supports, if any, the resident needs to administer the medication safely, taking into consideration that resident's needs and capabilities.

If a resident is receiving dietary accommodations to meet the resident's nutritional needs, including with respect to food allergies or intolerances and cultural, spiritual or personal preferences, the resident's personal service plan must describe those accommodations.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In addition to the content set out in sections 1 and 2 of this Schedule, a personal service plan for a resident of an assisted living residence of the Supportive Recovery class must include all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the steps the resident can take to protect and promote that resident's health and safety if that resident's residency ends under section 46 [unplanned end of residency] of the regulation, including with respect to accessing housing supports, professional health services and social services;
the name and contact information of the persons who must be notified under section 46 (a) of the regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are reportable incidents for the purposes of section 51 [reportable incidents]:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: aggression between residents means aggressive behaviour by a resident towards another resident that causes an injury that requires

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: first aid,
emergency care by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner, or
transfer to a hospital;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: aggressive or unusual behaviour means aggressive or unusual behaviour by a resident towards another person, including another resident, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has not been appropriately assessed in the resident's personal service plan, and
is not aggression between residents within the meaning of this Schedule;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: attempted suicide means an attempt by a resident to take the resident's own life;
choking means a choking incident involving a resident that requires

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: first aid,
emergency care by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner, or
transfer to a hospital;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: death means the death of a resident;
disease outbreak or occurrence means an outbreak or the occurrence of a disease above the incident level that is normally expected;

emotional abuse means any act, or lack of action, that may diminish the sense of dignity of a resident, perpetrated by a person who is not a resident, such as verbal harassment, yelling or confinement;
fall means a fall of such seriousness, experienced by a resident, as to require emergency care by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner, or transfer to a hospital;
financial abuse means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the misuse of the funds and assets of a resident by a person who is not a resident, or

the obtaining of the property and funds of a resident by a person who is not a resident without the knowledge and full consent of the resident or the resident's contact person or personal representative, if any;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: food poisoning means a food borne illness involving a resident that requires emergency care by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner, or transfer to a hospital;
medication error means an error in the administration or distribution of a medication that adversely affects a resident or requires emergency intervention or transfer to a hospital;
missing person means a resident who is missing;
motor vehicle injury means an injury to a resident that occurs during transit by motor vehicle while the resident is under the supervision of the registrant;
neglect means the failure of a registrant to meet the needs of a resident, including with respect to food and shelter;

other injury means an injury to a resident that requires emergency care by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner or transfer to a hospital, other than another type of incident described in this Schedule;

overdose means the introduction into a resident's body of toxic levels of medication, alcohol or illicit drugs that requires the administration of naloxone, emergency intervention or transfer to a hospital;
physical abuse means any physical force that is excessive for, or is inappropriate to, a situation involving a resident and perpetrated by a person who is not a resident;
poisoning means the ingestion of a poison or toxic substance by a resident, but does not include an overdose;
police call means a request for police to attend the residence;

service delivery problem means any condition or event that could reasonably be expected to impair the ability of the registrant or the registrant's employees to provide a hospitality service or assisted living service, or that affects the health or safety of residents;
sexual abuse,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to paragraph (b), includes any

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: sexual behaviour directed towards a resident, and
sexual exploitation of a resident, whether consensual or not, by an employee of the registrant or by any other person in a position of trust, power or authority, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not include consenting sexual behaviour between residents;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: unexpected illness means any unexpected illness of such seriousness that it requires a resident to receive emergency care by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner or transfer to a hospital.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Community Care and Assisted Living Act, S.B.C. 2002, c. 75, s. 34 (3) to (6).]
